author: nothrowaway4me
body:
There were a number of stocks I wanted to invest in but were just too expensive 30 days ago. Now the whole market has gotten destroyed. As someone who is young and doesn't need new money for many years, this is quite an opportunity.


So I'm slowly going with the absolute best companies, secular growth trends that won't change.


Currently getting into:

Technology: Amazon, Alibaba, Adobe, ServiceNow, Lam Research, Nvidia

Staples: Mondolez Cyclicals: Chipotle 

Energy: Enterprise Products Partners

Financials: BlackRock

Healthcare: Intuitive Surgical, Bristol-Meyers, Eli Lilly

author: mechtech
body:
The situation has changed after the 15% run up. Each day that the market moves +=5%, there is more movement under the surface than we were seeing over an entire month last year. Yesterday's smart entry might offer mediocre immediate value tomorrow.

That said, here are some examples from last week, before the 15% runup. All of these were actual purchases for a fairly large account looking for smart entries for longer term holds of 1-2 years at minimum (bottom price, current price). Any mention of value is referencing a situation closer to the bottom price than the current price.

Blackstone (37 -> 46): Private equity with a solid foundation was offering value and future growth, with a historical precedent for being a smart buy in such times.

Starbucks (50 -> 66): Quality company at a fairly good price. China recovery play. Bought leading into an analyst day with the assumption that it would soothe the extreme uncertainty and draw in some buyers (bought when VIX was 70+).

Capri Holdings (5.62 -> 11.67): Mispriced equity. Was priced below bankruptcy and/or forced asset sales to larger players. Immediate risk was short term debt, which was refinanced to 2023 two days after entry.

Ventas (17 -> 31): Mispriced. Priced at bankruptcy with a 20% dividend at the bottom.  REIT with exposures like healthcare that should be priced as under threat or distressed, not literally at liquidation prices. They reaffirmed dividend a few days after entry and the CEO did some PR.

Welltower (27 -> 50): Mispriced like VTR. Retirement home REIT trading with a 15% dividend yield. Strong strong value under the scenario of trending back to a "return to normalcy".

LAM research, KLA Tencor, ASML: All have had a decent bump. EUV silicon lithography transition will not be stopped by the virus. An absolute juggernaut of a market force to buy into and put up against the current crisis.

Nokia: 5g buy and hold. Mediocre company at a great price. (Sometimes this can have a place in a portfolio. If everything is bought because of the same factors like "quality company at a good price", the portfolio will likely share some outsized exposures that need to be hedged against.)

Discover Financial Services (25 -> 40): Strong consumer credit exposure. Incredible value otherwise. Once the Fed started stepping up to other asset classes it made sense to buy in. When the Fed announced CC debt could be used as collateral it made sense to go in hard. We saw two back to back 30% rises after buying in, probably because of the timely Fed pump.

Sabre (0.50 (yep) -> 6): Has an entrenched position in a lucrative market with a valuable tech infrastructure. Strong possibility for a 1000% return in the next 5-10 years from the $3 buy in, outstripping the bankruptcy possibility.

So there is a recurring theme that you want to try and step away from possible cliff-faces and step in front of possible positive events. Would CPRI be forced to pay the short term debt at the end of the year, have no cash, not be able to sell off quality intangible assets like Versace, not be able to negotiate with their bank, and not be able to refinance? Possibly, but there was arguably a better possibility that they would find some breathing room and stop the drowning and thus the share price.

author: ridenourt
body:
I think you are right about a snap back rally, however this is the start of the downtrend and we just passed the peak. the valuation on a lot of stocks was just way to high and the market was looking for a sell off.

This is all a bull trap though. we push higher Monday -Tuesday and possibly even into late Wednesday, however it's going to get bad when individual states start testing soon in NY, CA, WA, MA, FL, and OR. We are finally going to see how far this virus has really spread and it's not good.

Some interesting notes from the WHO report from China. 3.4% mortality rate which is higher than I thought. The 15% of people who need oxygen for 3-6 weeks and the 5% of people who need a ventilator which can be found on page 32. Pneumonia is closer to 30% and when they say mild it means the worst flu of your life. The US healthcare system will get completely shocked and if we start seeing rising numbers like South Korea or Italy there will be some serious pain. In addition other places like South America, Central America, and Africa could see death rates as high as 10-15% due to extremely poor health care.

Next the supply chain right now is completely screwed. Los Angeles saw a drop off 25% shipping in February which the last two weeks it was a reduction of almost 36%. In march they believe it could be a yoy drop of 40 % which is catastrophic. Any rally here would make a good short just buy Puts out a few months. I don't want to get into all the implications of if widget C isn't produced, but widget A, B, and D are here but make your own assumptions.

In addition I have traded for a long time and one thing I know is the market hates uncertainty. Supply chain, virus, and panic is not a model that can be priced in. I don't see any of these factors being settled any time soon.

author: VapesOnAPlane
body:
I mean I half agree with you. Yes you are right that this won't be like the 2008 financial collapse. However, the market was severely overvalued and still is. This new virus is just giving a reason to "correct" even more. Yes it's impossible to know where the exact bottom is but I think this has more room to go down. Example: MA still has a PE of 36, even after this correction right now. **Thirty Six!** Yeah they're a cash printing machine and one of the best stocks on the market, but that PE is not justified even for them. It should be between close to 30.

THAT SAID, there will likely be some industries that could fall close to what happened in 2008 - for example certain airline and gambling companies (AAL and LVS specifically). There was just a [report](https://www.reuters.com/article/us-macau-revenues/macaus-gaming-revenues-tumble-87-8-in-february-over-coronavirus-impact-idUSKBN20O1HH?il=0) that LVS saw a 90% reduction in revenue for February in Macau - which is where the overwhelming majority of their revenue comes from. I know they reopened the casinos there a few weeks ago but people are still not coming. What happens if people stop coming to Vegas too because of the virus? That could last a few more months. Remember, they have over $4B in cash on hand but $12B in debt. They will of course bounce back (and I'm sure Adelson would pump cash into it if needed when the time comes, just as he did in 2008/9), but they could literally see their stock fall 50% from where it is now (or even more).

author: RipeForInvesting
body:
Since this is an investing forum, let's forget whether it is or isn't blown out of proportion and look how the markets have reacted to the news.

Since Friday, we have more cases, more people dead (one on our home turf).  The worse part is they currently believe it could have been cryptically circulating in Washington for six weeks now.  About the best news, I've seen is the number of cases in China has slowed, at least if you believe them.

So, the things that triggered the correction have only gotten worse.  Hence why I said this week will most likely be redder.  There very well could be another announcement like you got from Apple/Mastercard/etc as icing on the cake.  

I'm personally not that concerned about the illness itself.  I am more concerned about potential disruptions.  It could seriously put a hurt on your income and life regardless.  I work in the school system part-time and if they were to say close a school down for two weeks, well there goes that income.  It goes beyond catching the illness itself.

I live in Atlanta, about 30 mins from Jackson Hartsfield, I can tell you that Georgia has been already making lots of preparations (I'm surprised because normally our state is four steps behind).

author: RayPowers
body:
I had a  short call on $MA  week after the JAN 2020 monthly's, but short call ( JAN 24 weekly)  was part of a debit call spread. Was ITM by almost 2 dollars, I wasn't assigned, however the other leg was exercised in my account creating a margin call w/TD. 

The high for the day on Monday (JAN 27) for $MA was about 4 dollars below close on Friday, which resulted in large loss (selling 100 shares to satisfy margin call).

My best guess to why it happened to me was the equity was down during the week and a trader or MM did not need to exercise the opposite of my short position. Your experience is the weekly after the FEB 2020 monthly's.

Did the non-assignment cost you a profit or were you simply selling the calls as a bearish position?

author: arzt506
body: yeah broker is super gay and doesn't have a convenient view like that. Horrible for bragging about gains. You can see the profit from the buy and sell activity here if you look at my buy in and my sell of each position but there's not really a better summary view. Sorry bro. Account went 3.5x last week. In hindsight I could have bought shorter dated puts on TQQQ and paid less premium but 2nd 3rd week of Feb was crazy melt up and I was nervous about a parabolic move in SPY and QQQ in particular and wanted to give myself more time for the bear thesis to play out. Market was trading at 3 standard devs above the 200 MA which was verging on tech bubble levels. Huge divergences building everywhere hence buying those puts when I did.
